text:
He took off his coat, wrapped himself in a blanket, and lay down on the bed. He felt annoyed. “I should’ve been feeling better for this,” he thought with a wry smile. The room was stuffy, the candle flickered weakly, and the wind howled outside. He heard a mouse scratching in the corner, and the place smelled like mice and leather. 

Lost in thought, he wanted to focus on something. “There must be a garden outside,” he mused. “I can hear trees rustling. Ugh, I hate that sound on a stormy night. It gives me the creeps.” He remembered how much he disliked it when he passed Petrovsky Park earlier. That thought led him to the bridge over the Little Neva, and he felt a chill, just like when he stood there. “I’ve never liked water,” he reflected, “even in pretty views.” 

Then, a strange idea made him smile: “Why do I care about comfort and taste right now? I’ve become picky, like an animal choosing a spot for a special moment. I should’ve gone into Petrovsky Park! But it felt dark and cold—ha-ha! As if I was looking for good vibes!” He suddenly wondered, “Why haven’t I blown out the candle?” So, he did. “They must be asleep next door,” he thought, not seeing the light peeking through the crack. 

“Alright, Marfa Petrovna, this is your moment. It’s dark, just perfect for you. But I guess you won’t show up!” 

He suddenly remembered how, just an hour before he planned to act on Dounia, he told Raskolnikov to let Razumihin take care of her. “I guess I really did…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist reflects on his discomfort and anxieties while lying in bed, contemplating his surroundings and the impending actions he must take.
